newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary Jews say Swiss list fraction of total.
newsitem.headline: Hungary Jews say Swiss list fraction of total.

text.p: Hungary's Jewish community said on Monday that a Swiss list of 33 former bank account owners was just a fraction of what they believed could be the total number of accounts of Hungarian holocaust victims.

"These are just those who had an account under their own name," Peter Feldmayer, President of the Association of Hungarian Jewish Communities (MAZSIHISZ), told Reuters. "Typically, these accounts were either unnamed or dummy accounts."
Switzerland on Monday handed Hungary the 33-name list of wartime accounts which were declared ownerless after World War Two and the money was credited to Budapest.

According to Hungarian foreign ministry sources, Switzerland and Hungary concluded a confidential protocol in 1973 by which Switzerland transferred 325,000 Swiss francs ($229,600) from bank deposits of Jews who perished in World War Two to the Hungarian government.
The protocol was attached to interstate property and wartime compensation agreements concluded in 1950 and 1973.
Feldmayer said it was almost impossible to estimate the actual number of accounts formerly held by Hungarian Jews but believed it could be "a few thousand at most".
He added that MAZSIHISZ will search for the inheritors and the rest of the money will go into a Jewish foundation to be set up shortly for administering primarily domestic compensation.

Last October Hungary's parliament approved a law creating a foundation to administer property confiscated from Hungarian Jews during World War Two and to oversee payments to survivors of the Nazi extermination campaign.
The government promised to set up the foundation in July after talks with the World Jewish Congress and other groups.
Some 600,000 of Hungary's 800,000 Jews perished in Nazi labour or concentration camps. There are an estimated 100,000 Jews in Hungary today, including 20,000 holocaust survivors.
